com.quantcomponents.algo.ta
Class AverageCrossingTradingAgent

java.lang.Object
  com.quantcomponents.algo.ta.AverageCrossingTradingAgent
All Implemented Interfaces:
IManagedRunnable, IOrderStatusListener, IPositionListener, ITradingAgent, ISeriesListener<Date,Double>, ISeriesProcessor<Date,Double>, Runnable
public class AverageCrossingTradingAgent
extends Object
implements ITradingAgent, ISeriesListener<Date,Double>

A trivial example of a trend following trading strategy. It starts folling the trend based on the crossing of a short moving average above or below a long moving average of the prices. When the short moving average crosses above the long one, it takes a long position, and vice-versa. Number of periods for short and long moving averages, trading calendar to be used, position size (short or long) are configurable. Also among the configuration parameters there is: ignoreLastPeriod: this parameter should be set when trading in real time, and not set when backtesting. In fact when trading in real time, only the completed periods must enter into the algorithm. When backtesting, all the periods must be taken into account, since otherwise the last of the series will not enter the test.
NOTEThis is only an example to show how to write trading algorithms with this framework: it has been proved consistenly loss-making!
